# Basic Longitudinal Models

This tutorial illustrates how to estimate simple longitudinal models using the panel structure of the data.

We assume the dataset contains:

- `id` – participant identifier  
- `wave` – measurement occasion  
- `autonomy` – autonomy satisfaction score  
- Additional covariates (e.g., age, gender, risk perception)

## 1. Linear mixed model

<!-- ```{r} -->
<!-- #| message: false -->
<!-- #| warning: false -->

<!-- library(tidyverse) -->
<!-- library(lme4) -->

<!-- data <- readr::read_csv("data/synthetic/synthetic_longitudinal.csv") -->

<!-- model <- lmer(autonomy ~ wave + (1 | id), data = data) -->

<!-- summary(model) -->
<!-- ``` -->

<!-- ## 2. Adding covariates -->

<!-- ```{r} -->
<!-- model_cov <- lmer(autonomy ~ wave + age + gender + (1 | id), data = data) -->

<!-- summary(model_cov) -->
<!-- ``` -->

For more advanced models (e.g., growth curve models, cross-lagged panel models), you can use packages such as `lavaan`, `nlme`, or `brms`.
